title: About
text:
About this site

# Load required libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(tidyr)

# Sample data for the chart
data <- data.frame(
  AgeGroup = c("60-77", "45-60", "30-44", "18-29", "13-17", "8-12", "6-8"),
  MoreThanFiveLies = c(1, 3, 4, 10, 11, 9, 9),
  OneToFiveLies = c(10, 13, 28, 35, 45, 43, 43),
  NoLies = c(89, 84, 68, 55, 45, 48, 48)
)

# Reshape the data for plotting
data_long <- data %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c("MoreThanFiveLies", "OneToFiveLies", "NoLies"),
               names_to = "LieFrequency",
               values_to = "Percentage")

# Define the order of the factors for AgeGroup and LieFrequency
data_long$AgeGroup <- factor(data_long$AgeGroup, levels = rev(data$AgeGroup))
data_long$LieFrequency <- factor(data_long$LieFrequency, 
                                 levels = c("NoLies", "OneToFiveLies", "MoreThanFiveLies"))

# Improved color palette
color_palette <- c("#d9d9d9", "#969696", "#525252")  # Light to dark grey

# Create the stacked bar plot
ggplot(data_long, aes(x = AgeGroup, y = Percentage, fill = LieFrequency)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "stack", width = 0.7) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = color_palette) +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Lying frequency, by age", subtitle = "Over a 24-hour period", 
       x = "Age Group", y = "Percentage of Lies", fill = "Lies Frequency") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "top", 
        plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
        plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12),
        legend.title = element_blank()) +
  geom_text(aes(label = paste0(Percentage, "%")), 
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5), 
            size = 3, color = "white")









# Load required libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)

# Sample data for the chart
data <- data.frame(
  AgeGroup = c("60-77", "45-60", "30-44", "18-29", "13-17", "8-12", "6-8"),
  MoreThanFiveLies = c(1, 3, 4, 10, 11, 9, 9),
  OneToFiveLies = c(10, 13, 28, 35, 45, 43, 43),
  NoLies = c(89, 84, 68, 55, 45, 48, 48)
)

# Reshape the data for plotting
data_long <- data %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c("MoreThanFiveLies", "OneToFiveLies", "NoLies"),
               names_to = "LieFrequency",
               values_to = "Percentage")

# Define the order of the factors for AgeGroup and LieFrequency
data_long$AgeGroup <- factor(data_long$AgeGroup, levels = rev(data$AgeGroup))
data_long$LieFrequency <- factor(data_long$LieFrequency, 
                                 levels = c("NoLies", "OneToFiveLies", "MoreThanFiveLies"))

# Updated pastel color palette
color_palette <- c("#f2f2f2", "#f7c6c7", "#FFEB84")  # Light grey, pastel pink, pastel yellow for 5+

# Create the stacked bar plot
p <- ggplot(data_long, aes(x = AgeGroup, y = Percentage, fill = LieFrequency)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "stack", width = 0.7) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = color_palette) +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Lying frequency, by age", subtitle = "Over a 24-hour period", 
       x = "Age Group", y = "Percentage of Lies", fill = "Lies Frequency") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "top", 
        plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
        plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12),
        legend.title = element_blank()) +
  geom_text(aes(label = ifelse(LieFrequency == "NoLies", paste0(Percentage, "%"), "")), 
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5), 
            size = 3, color = "black") +  # Black text for "No Lies"
  geom_text(aes(label = ifelse(LieFrequency != "NoLies", paste0(Percentage, "%"), "")), 
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5), 
            size = 3, color = "black")  # White text for other categories

# Display the plot
print(p)

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Dr.¬†Gordon Wright
Lecturer in Deception, Mind-reading and People-Watching

Chief Mischief Officer - LittleMonkeyLab

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text: New Slide

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text: Introduction

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Interpersonal Perception
How We Form Impressions

First impressions
Nonverbal cues
Verbal communication

Factors Influencing Perception

Stereotypes
Cultural differences
Personal experiences
Cognitive biases


Activity: ‚ÄúFirst Impressions Exercise‚Äù 1. Show participants a series of faces for 5 seconds each. 2. Ask them to write down their immediate impressions. 3. Discuss how these impressions were formed and what factors might have influenced them.

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Social Cognition
Definition and Importance

How we process, store, and apply information about others
The ‚Äúwhy‚Äù behind our social perceptions

Key Concepts

Schema theory
Attribution theory
Social categorization


Suggested image: A diagram of the human brain with areas highlighted that are associated with social cognition (e.g., prefrontal cortex, amygdala).

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Peoplewatching
Systematic Observation in Natural Settings

Observing behavior without interference
Identifying patterns and anomalies

Importance in Profiling

Provides real-world data
Helps validate or challenge existing theories
Reveals cultural and contextual influences on behavior


Activity: ‚ÄúVirtual Peoplewatching‚Äù 1. Show a short video clip of people in a public space (e.g., a busy street or cafe). 2. Ask participants to note interesting behaviors or interactions. 3. Discuss observations and potential interpretations as a group.

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Integration: A Comprehensive Approach
Combining Concepts

Interpersonal perception informs initial judgments
Social cognition explains the mental processes behind these judgments
Peoplewatching provides real-world validation and new insights

Real-World Application

Case study: Profiling in criminal investigations
Example: Creating consumer profiles for marketing


Suggested image: A flowchart showing how interpersonal perception, social cognition, and peoplewatching feed into the profiling process.

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Ethical Considerations
Important Ethical Issues

Privacy concerns
Potential for bias and discrimination
Misuse of profiling techniques

Guidelines for Ethical Profiling

Transparency
Accountability
Regular review and updates of methods


Activity: ‚ÄúEthical Dilemma Discussion‚Äù Present a scenario where profiling could be useful but also potentially problematic. Have participants discuss in small groups and present their conclusions.

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Conclusion
Key Takeaways

Psychological profiling is a multifaceted approach
Integration of various psychological concepts enhances accuracy
Real-world observation is crucial for validation
Ethical considerations must always be at the forefront

Future Directions

Advancements in AI and machine learning
Cross-cultural studies in profiling
Ongoing refinement of techniques


Suggested image: A word cloud featuring key terms from the lecture (e.g., perception, cognition, ethics, observation).

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Questions and Discussion
Thank you for your attention!
Any questions or topics you‚Äôd like to explore further?

Activity: ‚ÄúReflection and Application‚Äù Ask participants to write down one way they could apply what they‚Äôve learned in their personal or professional lives. Encourage voluntary sharing with the group.

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Prepare for Mind Explosion!

Forget everything you thought you knew about understanding people
We‚Äôre about to revolutionize your view of social interaction
Welcome to the wild world of Mind-space and people-watching!

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Introducing Mind-space


Every person‚Äôs mind exists in a multidimensional space
It‚Äôs like the Marvel multiverse, but for brains!
Minds are mapped based on traits, abilities, and quirks
YOU are constantly navigating this mind-boggling terrain

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
The Power of Mind-space


Not just abstract theory - the key to unlocking human behavior!
Every time you:

Size someone up
Predict their actions
Wonder ‚ÄúWhat were they thinking?!‚Äù

You‚Äôre tapping into the awesome power of Mind-space!

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
You‚Äôre Already a People-Watching Pro!


Think you‚Äôre not a mind-reader? Think again!
All that people-watching wasn‚Äôt just killing time
You‚Äôve been honing your Mind-space navigation skills
You‚Äôre a cosmic explorer of cognition!

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Mind-space in Action


Awkward first date? Mind-space misalignment!
Colleague who reads your mind? Mind-space maestro!
Friend who always surprises you? Mind-space pinball wizard!

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
section: Your Mission, Should You Choose to Accept It
text:
Your Mission, Should You Choose to Accept It


Become a certified Mind-space explorer
Chart the uncharted territories of the human psyche
Never look at people the same way again
Are you ready to have your mind expanded to cosmic proportions?

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Let‚Äôs Blast Off!
Into the thrilling world of Mind-space and people-watching we go!

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Introduction to Mind-space


A theoretical framework for understanding social cognition
Proposes that minds are represented in a multidimensional space
Similar to how faces are represented in ‚ÄúFace-space‚Äù (Valentine, 1991)
Aims to explain individual differences in theory of mind

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Key Components of Mind-space


Dimensions: Represent various aspects of minds (e.g., personality traits, cognitive abilities)
Location: Each mind occupies a specific point in the space
Mental States: Probability of specific mental states depends on location in Mind-space
Context: Situational factors interact with Mind-space location to determine mental states

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
The Science Behind Mind-space


Builds on established psychological concepts:

Theory of Mind (Premack & Woodruff, 1978)
Social cognition (Fiske & Taylor, 1991)
Individual differences in personality (e.g., Big Five; Costa & McCrae, 1992)

Integrates findings from cognitive neuroscience and social psychology

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Empirical Support for Mind-space


Studies show:

Accuracy of personality trait covariance predicts mental state inference (Conway et al., 2019)
People use trait information to infer mental states (Tamir & Thornton, 2018)
Individual differences in ability to locate minds in Mind-space (Conway et al., 2019)

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Mind-space and Theory of Mind


Explains variance in theory of mind ability
Accounts for both:

Accuracy of mental state inferences
Individual differences in this accuracy

Provides a framework for understanding atypical social cognition (e.g., in autism)

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Implications of Mind-space


For psychology: New approach to studying social cognition
For neuroscience: Testable hypotheses about neural representations of minds
For AI: Framework for developing more sophisticated social AI
For education and therapy: Potential for new interventions to improve social skills

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Future Directions


Investigating the development of Mind-space across the lifespan
Exploring cultural differences in Mind-space structure
Examining the neural correlates of Mind-space representations
Applying Mind-space concepts to improve human-AI interactions

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
Conclusion

Mind-space offers a powerful new lens for understanding social cognition
Bridges multiple areas of psychological and neuroscientific research
Opens up exciting new avenues for research and application

title: Psychology Taster Lecture
text:
What is Psychological Profiling?

Broad interpretation: Understanding and predicting behavior based on psychological characteristics
Applications:

Law enforcement
Marketing
Human resources
Clinical psychology



Suggested image: A collage showing diverse professions (detective, marketer, HR manager, psychologist) to illustrate various applications.
